column4: ususb  was designed in 96. so a 2000 system wl have usb although it may not be able to boot it
use ext2 if the storage is flash based. makes it last longer
or cli :)
gvfs-fuse as far as I know
oh, you can use smbmount or mount -t cifs
^^ "is optional" :-/
so I could add them to /etc/fstab?
absolutely
it's quite powerful :)
erUSUL: Is there any downside to mounting shares automatically (using /etc/fstab) with computers that are on 24/7?
none at all :)
ok thx, just curious :)
right click a file and select open with, then select the app you want to open that sort of file with
yes of course :), but can I trim down the associations with a particular filetype (mimetype?) so they show in the first-level menu? they used to do this, before I added more associations to them :)
I've looked in /etc/gnome/defaults.list, but it's kind of confusing :)
could edit ~/.local/share/applications/mimeapps.list
as far as I know it gets added but i've not used gnome for a time now
thanks, that helped me with some of it, but there's still (e.g. for png) firefox, gimp, and shotwell...I think if it's down below a certain number (2 or 3?) then it will show in the main menu...
that's enough ram for ubuntu
yes, I know
true :)
I basically want to have capslock do rightarrow, and shift + capslock do leftarrow...let me check that...
will keytouch remap other keys as well?
maybe, not sure
actually, the real question is, would it be able to send leftarrow when I press shift + caps
not sure, ive not used it
midori is pretty light too
I'm on my Android phone so technically yes
sup?
you said "hi gzz", and there's no such user, so I figured you're probably not using the tab key ;)
gah
when you see plymouth, press ESC and it will get out of the way and let you see whats actually happening
plymouth?
plymouth is the pointless boot splash Ubuntu uses
needlez, sandyd: I never get there, it only sits at a blinking cursor if I boot normally, i'm booting into the 'recovery mode' grub entry
www.ubuntugeek.com/how-to-fix-ubuntu-10-04-lts-lucid-blank-screen-at-startup.html - Cached
will check, brb
nope, none of those worked, it doesn't seem to be something with the graphics
what does it usually do after /scripts/init-bottom ?
what is?
mellin (gone now) referenced ayecee where he should have referenced Propel, so ayecee tried to ask him if he meant that, but he made the same error due to autocomplete ;)
thats not ironic
uk english?
Uk, Leeds, West Yorkshire
US here, probably a difference in terms :)
it'd have been ironic if the nick was 'accuracy' or something like that, Yeah the US 'ironic' is the UK 'coincidence', makes us all laugh over here
oh yes, not a coincidence, but ironic because in trying to correct he made the same error as the one being corrected :)
i guess, makes sense :D
blame the manufacturers of the hardware
or try Lubuntu
that's the last thing i put on it, it doesn't boot either, hangs at /scripts/init-bottom, same as ubuntu
did you MD5 test the ISO you downloaded?
yes, has nothing to do with that :)
try some boot options then is all I can suggest
the machine never ran the ubuntu livecd, although the lubuntu livecd did work (i used the alt when installing ubuntu)
i've tried rw /bin/bash, rw /init/sbin, noapic, vga=791, irqpoll, noacpi, and nolapic, to no avail :(
hmm, got latest BIOS?
tested RAM health?
haven't checked...grub2 works fine, as does the start of the boot process
worth a check, also disable as much of the BIOS functionality as you can to make the hardware limited nd basic
it doesn't have anything like that, only boot order, hdd test, and showing what you've got :)
well it has to be something so simply dismissing suggestions like that is ridficulous
ridficulous? :D
what did i dismiss?
you know what I mean. I'm on my 4 day so I'm flagging a bit
i was saying that the bios doesn't have anything for turning off features, it's quite old :)
sure it does, you can disable USB and onboard audio etc. I have a P200 backup server where you can turn hardware off and on
its probably older than you

not this, the only things you can change are: time/date, a few passwords, boot order and floppy/cd enable/disable, f10 delay, parallel port mode, and hdd self-test (that is from looking at every single page and option right now) :)
wow thats pretty poor
you should see the laptop i made into a picture frame, it had nothing but boot order :D
you could pin a LOT of apps and get the desired result
this is an 8.10, but I don't think I can upgrade the packages...
8.10 is long dead dude, I'd clea install Lucid, Maverick or Natty (Natty is released in April this year)
don't really want to set up again :( all it's really running is squid, dansguardian, and iptables filtering...
you can get the alternate ISO of Jaunty and upgrade to that, keep going like that til you get to a supported release
may do that
how is upgrading from a cd different than from dist-upgrade, or would the latter not be possible due to being out of support?
dist-upgrade is similar to upgrade, you will stay on the same release
ah
you can use the alternate CD of the next release to get the next release (or LTS -> LTS upgrade etc)
right
does the cd (booting) have an option to upgrade, or do you do it from the os?
do it from within the OS, there is basically a script in the root of the CD (Or ISO, both are equal (saves having to burn a CD)) to run and update
ok sweet :) I can't find any info on google about it though, lemme pull out a cd
it must be the alternate CD to do it
not server cd?
no, only alternate
but alternate will update a server install? (sorry for all the ques :P)
yes it will upgrade any
ok
so I guess /cdromupgrade (from http://old-releases.ubuntu.com/releases/jaunty/ubuntu-9.04-alternate-i386.list)...
good luck :)
kinda like vnc you mean?
